mapping_result.mapping_notes: Existing functions cover some aspects of data protection but do not fully identify all sensitive data types as required.
Current functions ensure encryption and private IP configuration but do not fully identify storage locations of sensitive data.
Existing functions provide encryption and secure transmission but do not cover all security controls for sensitive data.
No existing functions directly validate sensitive data presence and protection; a new function is needed.
Existing functions do not cover transaction data identification; a new function is necessary to meet the requirement.
Existing functions cover encryption and asset identification, but a specific function to identify cryptographic implementations is needed.
IAM functions provide good coverage for account management, but a specific function to identify all accounts and credentials is needed.
Current functions address configuration compliance but do not specifically identify sensitive configuration options.
Asset identification is covered, but a specific function to list sensitive functions is needed.
Existing functions address encryption and access restrictions, but a function to identify sensitive data storage locations is needed.
Existing functions help in identifying critical assets but do not fully cover compliance verification for third-party software guidance.
Current functions identify critical assets but do not maintain an inventory or classification, which is required for full compliance.
Existing functions relate to instance-specific configurations but do not address scanning or documentation of exposed interfaces.
Existing IAM functions cover authentication integrity but do not specifically address external resources for authentication.
Existing functions ensure TLS and certificate management but do not fully cover verification of external data protection resources.
Existing functions provide logging and tracing capabilities but do not directly address checking for publicly disclosed vulnerabilities.
Current functions help with network security but do not provide direct mitigation for known vulnerabilities in software interfaces.
Existing functions provide some access control but do not specifically address third-party module exposure.
Existing functions ensure secure configurations but do not explicitly verify all security controls are enabled on installation.
Existing functions support logging and auditing but do not ensure data processing occurs only after security initialization.
The existing functions ensure no default usage and enforce access policies, but a specific function to enable all security controls by default is needed.
Current functions cover the absence of default usage but do not explicitly verify default credentials. A new function is needed for comprehensive coverage.
Testing for the absence of default credentials requires a specific function to ensure compliance.
While existing functions prevent default usage, guidance on changing credentials needs a dedicated function.
Verification post-installation is crucial to ensure no default credentials are active, requiring a specific function.
The existing functions partially cover the requirement by ensuring no root access keys and instance-specific SSH keys are used. However, a specific check for default IAM credentials is needed.
Existing functions ensure IAM policies are attached to trusted identities and authentication mechanisms are intact. Additional checks for minimal privilege assignment are required.
Current functions help identify critical assets and categorize events, but a specific check for implemented security mechanisms is needed.
Existing functions provide good coverage for checking file permissions and instance compliance, aligning well with the requirement.
While existing functions ensure secure configurations and authorization modes, a specific check for legacy feature usage is necessary.
Existing functions help ensure that default accounts do not have excessive privileges, aligning with the principle of least privilege.
Existing functions provide a way to verify that default accounts are properly managed and do not have unnecessary privileges.
Existing functions help ensure that account privileges are limited, but additional checks for API protection are necessary.
Existing functions assist in identifying and managing sensitive data retention policies effectively.
Existing functions provide a means to verify that sensitive data retention functions are properly supported.
Existing functions provide partial coverage by restricting access and ensuring encryption. Additional function needed to ensure secure memory location configuration.
No existing functions directly address secure deletion of persistent sensitive data. A new function is required to automate secure deletion.
Secure deletion must consider platform-specific issues. A new function is needed to address these challenges.
Forensic analysis requires additional support to verify secure deletion. New function needed to assist in this verification.
Transient data requires secure deletion from temporary storage. A new function is needed to automate this process.
Existing functions provide partial coverage by ensuring access restrictions and fault prevention, but do not directly address secure deletion of transient data.
Existing functions help in restricting access but do not cover the identification of sensitive data residue.
Logging functions provide partial coverage by enabling audit logs, but do not directly analyze sensitive data leakage.
Existing functions provide data masking and encryption, but additional cryptographic protection is needed.
Existing IAM functions specify security requirements but do not ensure user guidance is provided.
Existing functions help verify installed applications and pod security, but a specific function to check security settings is needed.
Existing functions enforce MFA and access policies, but a function to check user input authentication is necessary.
Existing functions verify pod security and application versions, but a function for execution environment settings is lacking.
Existing functions assist with fault prevention and inventory reporting, but a function for checking mitigation controls is required.
Existing functions cover MFA and service account usage, but a function to define authentication requirements is not present.
Existing functions cover aspects of authentication mechanisms and service account usage, but may not fully address all aspects of the requirement.
Existing functions help enforce access policies but lack specific guidance on third-party VPN configurations.
Existing functions focus on key rotation but do not specifically identify sensitive data related to authentication.
Existing functions help enforce user role policies but may not fully ensure unique identification for all authentication methods.
Existing functions provide some supply chain protection but do not ensure unique identification for automated access.
Existing functions help ensure unique identification and restrict shared accounts, but additional controls may be needed for comprehensive coverage.
Existing functions ensure that shared accounts are not used, but further verification mechanisms may be necessary.
Existing functions help ensure strong authentication methods, but additional testing and evaluation functions may be required.
Existing functions provide some assurance of robust methods, but further evaluation capabilities are needed.
Existing functions ensure some level of security for authentication methods, but comprehensive testing functions are needed.
Existing functions help ensure that service accounts and IAM policies are configured to restrict access to critical assets based on least privilege.
Existing functions can verify that access to critical assets is restricted and correlate access levels with defined policies.
Existing functions ensure that sensitive data is stored securely and that access is restricted, with encryption options available.
Existing functions can confirm that security controls are in place to protect sensitive data during storage.
A new function is needed to specifically check compliance of cryptographic methods used for sensitive data.
Existing functions cover data masking and access restrictions, but a specific function for index token validation is needed.
Current functions provide platform information, but additional validation of security properties is required.
Functions for checking malicious code and transparency exist, but specific third-party vulnerability checks are needed.
Existing functions cover encryption and ingress controls, but identification of sensitive data transmission locations is required.
Functions for encryption and firewall rules are in place, but verification of encryption for sensitive data is required.

Existing function checks for SSL certificates but does not ensure enforcement of secure protocols.
No existing functions directly verify the enforcement of strong cryptography during transmission.

No existing functions verify the provision of guidance for third-party cryptography methods.

Existing functions enable logging but do not provide guidance for external system integration.

Existing functions provide logging but do not address secure handling of failures in tracking mechanisms.

Existing functions do not specifically address the requirement for periodic integrity checks.
Existing functions do not cover the protection of cryptographic primitives specifically.
Existing functions provide some coverage for protecting sensitive data but may not fully address the requirement.
Existing functions do not specifically ensure integrity protections during configuration updates.
Existing functions provide partial coverage for network-level protections. A new function is needed to specifically address detection of anomalous behavior in application-level interactions.
Current functions enable transparency but do not ensure third-party tool configuration. A new function is needed to validate third-party tool configurations.
Existing functions help ensure security baselines but do not cover threat identification comprehensively. A new function is needed for threat identification.
Data classification functions exist, but attack validation against standards is not covered. A new function is necessary for comprehensive validation.
Existing functions partially cover the mitigation process. A new function is needed to validate the implementation and effectiveness of mitigations.

Existing functions help in logging and tracing which can be part of the testing process but do not directly address vulnerability scanning. A new function is needed for integrating vulnerability scanning.
Current functions provide logging and traceability but lack direct vulnerability detection capabilities. A new function is needed for comprehensive vulnerability detection.
No existing functions directly support vulnerability ranking and remediation planning. A new function is necessary to ensure compliance with this requirement.
No existing functions directly manage the release of software updates. A new function is needed to automate this process.
Current functions do not address security update testing and release. A new function is required to ensure updates are managed and released appropriately.
Existing functions provide some level of security but do not directly verify software update integrity. A new function is needed for direct integrity checks.
No existing functions provide stakeholder guidance on software update verification. A new function is needed.
Existing function checks SSL certificates but does not ensure compliant cipher suites. A new function is needed for full compliance.
No existing functions address stakeholder notifications for software updates. A new function is needed.
Existing function provides transparency but does not notify stakeholders of vulnerabilities. A new function is needed.
Existing functions provide partial coverage for logging and auditing but do not fully address the integrity verification of updates.
Existing functions focus on identity and access management but do not provide direct guidance on secure implementation.
Existing functions address some security aspects but do not cover comprehensive guidance on third-party software installation and configuration.
Existing functions provide some access control but do not specifically address the retention of sensitive authentication data.

No existing GCP functions directly verify RNG compliance with terminal PTS evaluation.
No existing GCP functions ensure that clear-text data is not shared with unauthorized software.
Existing functions do not cover secure integration of shared resources as per vendor guidance.
While network segregation is covered, application-level segregation requires additional controls.
No existing functions ensure cryptographic signing and verification of software files.
Existing functions partially cover the requirement by ensuring no malicious code and checking root path integrity. Additional function needed for comprehensive software integrity verification.
Existing functions help ensure environment confidentiality and trusted images, but additional input validation enforcement is needed to fully mitigate attack vectors.
Fault prevention partially addresses error handling, but a specific function for verifying secure error handling is needed.
Limiting SSH sessions helps reduce race conditions, but a dedicated function for race condition prevention is needed.
Disabling privileged mode in Cloud Build helps, but a specific function for automated vulnerability testing is required.

This requirement is primarily documentation and guidance-based, which is not directly implementable via GCP API calls. A new function is suggested to check for compliance with guidance on GCP-hosted terminals.

This requirement involves adherence to vendor-specific guidance, which is not directly verifiable via GCP APIs. A new function is suggested to verify compliance with vendor guidance on GCP-hosted terminals.
While GCP does not directly provide an SBOM cataloging function, Security Center can be used to list assets, which can be part of an SBOM process.
GCP Security Center can be leveraged to identify asset relationships, aiding in the documentation of dependencies for SBOM.
Using GCP Security Center to list assets and their dependencies can help document the production environment dependencies for SBOM.
No existing GCP functions directly support SBOM tracking. A new function is needed to integrate SBOM generation and tracking into the build process.
Automated SBOM generation on updates is not covered by existing GCP functions. A new function is required to automate this within Cloud Build.
While Security Command Center can identify risks, a specific function for third-party component vulnerability monitoring is needed.
No current GCP function verifies the authenticity of fetched components. A new function is needed for this verification process.
Existing IAM and GKE functions provide partial coverage for access control, but a specific function for sensitive function access control is needed.
Existing functions cover enforcing access policies and securing endpoints, but a specific function to verify strong authentication mechanisms is needed.
MFA enforcement and key rotation provide strong credential protection, but additional verification of protection strength is needed.
Access transparency helps ensure secure enforcement, but a specific function for authentication decision enforcement is needed.
Existing functions provide strong coverage for restricting access to authorized users only through network and firewall configurations.
Firewall rules and access policies provide significant coverage, but a specific function to verify interface access restrictions is needed.
Existing functions help enforce access policies and restrict full access, contributing to fine-grained access control.
Existing functions enforce access policies, but additional functions may be needed for real-time authorization checks.
Existing functions help enforce access policies, but may not fully cover secure area enforcement.
Existing functions provide authentication and restrict access to sensitive functions, aligning with the requirement.
Existing functions restrict access to Internet-accessible interfaces, ensuring only authorized users can access.
Existing functions help restrict access but may not fully cover all aspects of explicitly authorized users for all software functions.
Current functions provide some level of protection but do not specifically address parser configurations.
Existing functions help manage firewall rules but do not specifically address resource starvation attacks.
Current functions provide some level of protection but do not specifically address validation of file content.
Existing functions provide some protection but do not specifically address hostile object creation and data tampering.
Existing functions provide some coverage for protecting web interfaces, but a dedicated function for web application firewall configuration is needed for complete compliance.
Existing functions address encryption of sensitive data transmissions, but additional functions for mutual authentication and certificate management may be required for comprehensive coverage.
